text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

Subsections 9.6.2.1 through 9.6.2.1.2 reﬂect the IRS requirement that IR manuals address Internal Controls (ICs). The ICs mandate is outlined in The Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and Understanding of Internal Controls memo dated September 14, 2016. Internal Controls are the program manuals policies and procedures. The ICs describe the program manual’s objectives, and officials charged with management and oversight. The ICs ensure the:
Controls (ICs). The ICs mandate is outlined in The Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and Understanding of Internal Controls memo dated September

Internal Controls are the program manuals policies and procedures. The ICs describe the program manual’s objectives, officials charged with management and oversight. The ICs ensure the: a. Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated and key terms are deﬁned; and b. Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations. (
) To conform to the new ICs standards: a. Former subsection

, Overview, is retitled to Program Scope and Objectives to reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates program manual’s mission, objectives, and goals. The subsection provides special agent assistance in conducting criminal investigations and associated litigation activities. b. New subsection
provides the legal authorities for the program manual (Plea Agreements and Sentencing Process). c. New subsection
adds a compiled list of the terms and acronyms used within the program manual (Plea Agreements and Sentencing Process). (

Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated and key terms are deﬁned; and Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations.
a. Former subsection

, Overview, is retitled to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates the program manual’s mission, objectives, and goals. The subsection provides special agent assistance in conducting criminal investigations and associated litigation activities. b. New subsection
provides the legal authorities for the program manual (Plea Agreements and Sentencing Process). c. New subsection
adds a compiled list of the terms and acronyms used within the program manual (Plea Agreements and Sentencing Process).

Former subsection 9.6.2.1, Overview, is retitled to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates the program manual’s mission, objectives, and goals. The subsection provides special agent assistance in conducting criminal investigations and associated litigation activities. New subsection 9.6.2.1.1 provides the legal authorities for the program manual (Plea Agreements and Sentencing Process).
Additional revisions, deletions, and grammatical changes were made throughout the section, which did not result in substantive changes but contributed to the procedural clarity of the subject matter.

Trial and Court Related (

) A taxpayer may enter into a plea agreement with the government at any of an investigation. CI does not have authority to initiate plea negotiations Plea the taxpayer because this authority rests solely with the DOJ. A taxpayer Situations be represented by counsel to initiate plea discussions or negotiations. Note: If a taxpayer is not represented by counsel and expresses an interest in negotiation discussions, advise the taxpayer that they must be by counsel in order to participate. (

) In an administrative investigation involving legal source income, when a taxpayer, through counsel, expresses a desire to participate in the plea program, inform the taxpayer and his/her counsel that the willingness enter into plea negotiations with DOJ in no way reduces the taxpayer’s ultimate civil tax liability. (
) These investigations do not require the same degree of preparation as administrative tax investigations since they will not go to trial. (
) The investigations do require that sufficient evidence be obtained to under the a referable matter that would meet the requirements of Fed. R. Crim. P.
Plea Program (b)(
) and the charges established by the investigation would adequately (Tax address the crime(s) committed by the taxpayer.

) The IRS will take precautions to ensure that information furnished by the taxpayer, prior to formal plea discussions with DOJ, will not be prohibited future use under the restrictions of Fed. R. Crim. P.
(f) in the event that negotiations fail by reason of withdrawal or rejection by DOJ. (

) The expedited plea program procedure is designed to accommodate the interests of taxpayers who desire a speedy resolution of the investigation prosecution, as well as the interest of the government in obtaining an ate resolution with the appropriate expenditure of investigative and prosecutorial resources. (

) Taxpayers requesting use of the expedited plea program procedure will be expected to cooperate with the IRS in the determination and satisfaction of their civil tax liabilities, as well as the criminal aspects. In the event the investigation is completed by use of these procedures without establishing appropriate civil deﬁciencies, the appropriate operating division of the IRS complete the civil investigation. (

) For a plea agreement to be acceptable under the expedited plea program, must: a. involve legal source income b. establish culpability for the violations charged c. include the most signiﬁcant violation d. consider the totality of the fraud committed by the taxpayer e. not reduce tax return felony counts to misdemeanors Note: Investigations in which the taxpayer does not appear willing to enter an acceptable plea, or where the investigation has not lished the general scope of the taxpayer’s culpability, are inappropriate for inclusion in this program.
9.6 Trial and Court Related Activities

In an administrative investigation involving legal source income, when a taxpayer, through counsel, expresses a desire to participate in the expedited plea program, inform the taxpayer and his/her counsel that the willingness to enter into plea negotiations with DOJ in no way reduces the taxpayer’s ultimate civil tax liability.
These investigations do not require the same degree of preparation as normal administrative tax investigations since they will not go to trial.
Agreements and Sentencing Process 9.6.2

) When a taxpayer, represented by counsel, expresses a desire to negotiate plea agreement prior to the formal completion of an administrative tion, the SA will advise taxpayer’s counsel of the following: a. Authority to engage in plea negotiations rests exclusively with DOJ. b. Counsel for the taxpayer must provide a written statement to CI ing the taxpayer’s desire to engage immediately in plea negotiations DOJ. The IRS will make a referral to DOJ by forwarding the written proposal to enter a plea of guilty to the charges being investigated. If approved by DOJ, Tax Division, it will be referred to the appropriate Attorney’s office for plea negotiations. c. The taxpayer must be informed that he/she will be required to plead the most signiﬁcant violation involved, consistent with the Tax Major Count Policy. d. Plea negotiations have to be conducted by either the respective US ney’s office or by DOJ, Tax Division. e. The taxpayer must submit to an interview by the SA and anything any information furnished can be used against the taxpayer in a prosecution, as well as in any civil settlement. f. The taxpayer must provide all records or information in his/her or to which the taxpayer has access, to the IRS for the years g. The charges being investigated and any proposal to enter into plea tiations can be referred to DOJ, Tax Division only after CI is able to corroborate the elements of the offense being investigated or the sions being made by the taxpayer (e.g., gross income in a
USC investigation or documentation relating to an unreported material in a
USC
) investigation, etc.). CI must have sufficient evidence to constitute a referable matter to DOJ. (

) The investigating SA should review all records in enough detail to ensure there are no signiﬁcant undiscovered issues or tax losses in the that have not been taken into account in assessing the merits of the DOJ, Tax Division. (

) The SA should secure and review the taxpayer’s returns for all years quent to the years under investigation and any open prior years to address issues raised by those returns in assessing the merits of the referral. (
) The SA should inquire and obtain the details, if appropriate, as to any (open or closed) Federal, state, or local investigations relating to the (

) If CI determines that a referral for plea negotiations would be in the best interests of the government, CT Counsel will be contacted for pre-referral sistance on the issues of whether: a. The presently available evidence is sufficient to meet the Fed. R. Crim P.

), speciﬁcally that a factual basis exists to the plea of guilty to each of the counts considered for referral. b. The charges established by the investigation adequately address the crime(s) committed by the taxpayer. (

) At the option of the SAC, if CT Counsel concurs with CI that a referral be made, CT Counsel will contact the taxpayer’s counsel orally or in writing accomplish the following: Internal Revenue Manual

When a taxpayer, represented by counsel, expresses a desire to negotiate a plea agreement prior to the formal completion of an administrative investiga- tion, the SA will advise taxpayer’s counsel of the following:

a. Authority to engage in plea negotiations rests exclusively with DOJ. b. Counsel for the taxpayer must provide a written statement to CI ing the taxpayer’s desire to engage immediately in plea negotiations DOJ. The IRS will make a referral to DOJ by forwarding the written proposal to enter a plea of guilty to the charges being investigated. If approved by DOJ, Tax Division, it will be referred to the appropriate US Attorney’s office for plea negotiations. c. The taxpayer must be informed that he/she will be required to plead to the most signiﬁcant violation involved, consistent with the Tax Division’s Major Count Policy. d. Plea negotiations have to be conducted by either the respective US ney’s office or by DOJ, Tax Division. e. The taxpayer must submit to an interview by the SA and anything said any information furnished can be used against the taxpayer in a criminal prosecution, as well as in any civil settlement. f. The taxpayer must provide all records or information in his/her or to which the taxpayer has access, to the IRS for the years involved. g. The charges being investigated and any proposal to enter into plea tiations can be referred to DOJ, Tax Division only after CI is able to corroborate the elements of the offense being investigated or the admis- sions being made by the taxpayer (e.g., gross income in a
USC investigation or documentation relating to an unreported material matter in a
USC
) investigation, etc.). CI must have sufficient evidence to constitute a referable matter to DOJ.
The SA should inquire and obtain the details, if appropriate, as to any other (open or closed) Federal, state, or local investigations relating to the taxpayer.
9.6 Trial and Court Related Activities

a. Conﬁrm that the taxpayer wants to enter into plea negotiations with b. Remind the taxpayer and his/her counsel of the charges being gated and that the government will only consider a plea that addresses those speciﬁc charges, i.e., the government will generally looking for a plea of guilty to one or more of the speciﬁed charges. c. Conﬁrm that the taxpayer is willing to be interviewed by the SA and the taxpayer will submit all records or information in his/her to which he/she has access to the IRS for the tax years involved. (

) If the taxpayer’s counsel wants to proceed with negotiations, the SAC or Counsel will request the taxpayer’s counsel provide a written statement conﬁrms the taxpayer’s wish to immediately engage in plea negotiations the US Attorney or DOJ, Tax Division. (

) The US Attorney’s office or DOJ will be responsible for negotiating any agreement during a grand jury investigation. If a plea involves tax Jury authorization must be obtained from DOJ, Tax Division. (
) The taxpayer and his/her counsel will be informed that the willingness to into plea negotiations with DOJ in no way reduces the taxpayer’s ultimate tax liability. (
) The taxpayer must be informed that he/she will be required to plead to the most signiﬁcant violation involved, consistent with the Tax Division’s Major Count Policy. (

) After the written statement is provided and is deemed legally sufficient by Counsel, the SA will forward a modiﬁed prosecution recommendation containing the following information: Report a. The title page of the prosecution recommendation report will state this matter involves a proposed plea agreement, and is a limited to DOJ only for purposes of negotiation, and if possible, ﬁnalizing a b. The taxpayer’s identiﬁcation, personal history, and a history of or income-producing activities. c. The nature of the taxpayer’s fraudulent activity and the evidence, including available exhibits, to support acceptance of a plea to the charges under investigation. d. Any indication of non-tax crimes (Federal, state, or local) for which taxpayer may be or has been under investigation. e. A recommendation for prosecution. f. Documentation that the taxpayer and/or the representative have all available records for all years involved in the investigation so it is there are no signiﬁcant undiscovered issues in the investigation which have not been taken into account in assessing the merits of the tion. This documentation should include all relevant conduct, which is necessary for presentation to the court for sentencing purposes. g. A description of the nature and extent of the records supplied and speciﬁc conclusions reached by the SA and/or revenue agent who reviewed them. h. Documentation of interview(s) with the taxpayer that reﬂect a review of the issues in the investigation. (The taxpayer must submit interview(s)).
Conﬁrm that the taxpayer wants to enter into plea negotiations with DOJ. Remind the taxpayer and his/her counsel of the charges being investi

gated and that the government will only consider a plea that adequately addresses those speciﬁc charges, i.e., the government will generally be looking for a plea of guilty to one or more of the speciﬁed charges. Conﬁrm that the taxpayer is willing to be interviewed by the SA and that the taxpayer will submit all records or information in his/her possession or to which he/she has access to the IRS for the tax years involved.

a. The title page of the prosecution recommendation report will state that this matter involves a proposed plea agreement, and is a limited referral to DOJ only for purposes of negotiation, and if possible, ﬁnalizing a plea. b. The taxpayer’s identiﬁcation, personal history, and a history of business or income

producing activities. c. The nature of the taxpayer’s fraudulent activity and the evidence, including available exhibits, to support acceptance of a plea to the charges under investigation. d. Any indication of non

tax crimes (Federal, state, or local) for which the taxpayer may be or has been under investigation. e. A recommendation for prosecution. f. Documentation that the taxpayer and/or the representative have provided all available records for all years involved in the investigation so it is clear there are no signiﬁcant undiscovered issues in the investigation which have not been taken into account in assessing the merits of the tion. This documentation should include all relevant conduct, which is necessary for presentation to the court for sentencing purposes. g. A description of the nature and extent of the records supplied and the speciﬁc conclusions reached by the SA and/or revenue agent who reviewed them. h. Documentation of interview(s) with the taxpayer that reﬂect a thorough review of the issues in the investigation. (The taxpayer must submit to interview(s)).
and Sentencing Process

page i. A complete and thorough discussion of the nature and extent of the tax- payer’s cooperation. j. A summary and evaluation of the taxpayer’s returns for all years under vestigation, and subsequent to the years under investigation, addressing any issues raised by those returns in assessing the merits of the tion. This summary will, where practical, include a computation reﬂecting the tax ramiﬁcations of the taxpayers’ actions. k. A discussion as to the potential range of sentences the taxpayer may receive based on the evidence available for use under the Sentencing Guidelines. (

) Criminal Tax Counsel will review the prosecution recommendation report for legal sufficiency pursuant to these guidelines. Criminal Tax Counsel will prepare a CEM for the SAC, which reﬂects CT Counsel’s evaluation of the merits of the criminal prosecution. Contained within the CEM will be a noting CT Counsel’s concurrence or nonconcurrence with the prosecution ommendation. (

) If it is determined that prosecution is warranted, the SAC will refer the gation to DOJ, Tax Division, recommending prosecution and the initiation of plea negotiations in accordance with the written request of taxpayer’s a. A copy of the prosecution recommendation report with exhibits will be forwarded to: Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General US Department of Justice, Tax Division
M Street, NE Washington, DC

Attn: (Name), Chief (Northern/Southern/Western) Division Criminal Enforcement Section (Send to the attention of the appropriate Enforcement Section Chief) b. The SAC will telephone the DOJ liaison attorney to state that such a report is being submitted to their office. The DOJ attorney will contact SAC by telephone to acknowledge receipt of the report. (
) The DOJ, Tax Division has

days after receipt of the referral from the SAC either authorize prosecution consistent with the proposed plea bargain, or approve the negotiation of such a plea. a. If DOJ, Tax Division objects to proceeding with the plea discussions, or the evidence submitted is insufficient to meet the requirements of Tax Division Directive III, and Fed. R. Crim. P.

(f), DOJ, the Tax Division immediately notify the SAC. For administrative investigations, DOJ, Tax Division will then notify the taxpayer’s counsel in writing that the gation is being returned to the IRS and all exhibits and ﬁles will be returned to the IRS. b. If DOJ, Tax Division authorizes prosecution, it will refer all documents the appropriate US Attorney’s Office, who may then undertake plea tiations with the taxpayer and his/her counsel. The US Attorney’s Office may accept a plea to the speciﬁed major count without further tion from DOJ, Tax Division. If the US Attorney’s office desires to a plea to any count other than the speciﬁed major count, the approval DOJ, Tax Division is required. Internal Revenue Manual

) No information or evidence submitted to the US Attorney by the taxpayer counsel during the course of plea negotiations will be forwarded to the IRS unless they expressly authorize the IRS’ use of such information. In these ations, a written waiver of the Rule
(f) restrictions should be obtained. (
) Upon return of an investigation, the IRS, after considering all relevant facts, determine whether to continue with the investigation. (

) The SAC will approve the prosecution recommendation report and make appropriate referral. or (

) If the SAC does not approve the recommendation of the SA, the SAC will of prepare a memorandum documenting or explaining the reason(s) for not in Charge approving the prosecution recommendation report. The memorandum and Prosecution prosecution recommendation report will be returned to the originating SSA. (

) For sensitive investigations (those involving any of the following: a currently serving elected Federal official, a currently serving Article III judge; a serving high-level Executive Branch official; a currently serving elected statewide official; a currently serving member of the highest court of the a mayor currently serving a population of

or more; perjury in the Tax Court; or an exempt organization), the SAC will forward the recommendation report to the DFO with a brief cover memorandum asking the concurrence of the DFO. The investigation may not be referred until written concurrence of the DFO is obtained. See IRM
, General, and Subject Investigations for sensitive investigations. (

) One of the goals of the criminal prosecution process is having the Court restitution. Similar to incarceration, restitution acts as a criminal deterrent in Plea would be offenders. Restitution is often ordered in criminal tax cases to a plea agreement and may be ordered as a component of the sentence solely as a condition of probation or supervised release. (

) It is in the best interest of the Service for the plea to be signed and to cally address the criminal restitution amounts as a criminal penalty or component of the sentence and not solely as a condition of probation or vised release. This is especially important for a Title

offenses and Title offenses for failure to pay a tax because of the potential limitations placed the assessment of the restitution and the collection of the restitution. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
U
9.6 Trial and Court Related Activities

No information or evidence submitted to the US Attorney by the taxpayer or counsel during the course of plea negotiations will be forwarded to the IRS unless they expressly authorize the IRS’ use of such information. In these situ- ations, a written waiver of the Rule 11(f) restrictions should be obtained.
Plea Agreements and Sentencing Process

) In plea cases, the SA and AUSA should examine the language in the plea work towards language that outlines the defendant’s agreement to pay tion as a criminal penalty. Note: In light of United States v. Westbrooks,
F.
d
th Cir.
), vacated and remanded on other grounds,
S.Ct.
), in certain situations, particularly for Title
offenses and Title

offenses for failure pay a tax, criminal restitution ordered solely as a condition of probation or supervised release severely restricts the assessment and the collection of the restitution. As a result, every effort should be made by the SA and to ensure the restitution is ordered as an independent part of the sentence and not as a condition of probation or supervised release. See IRM
for more. (

) Including restitution as part of the plea agreement is an effective method for the AUSA to facilitate civil resolution of a criminal case and the inclusion of taxpayer’s cooperation in the civil settlement as part of the plea agreement. See LEM
for court ordered restitution for refund crimes. (

) The ultimate goal of every criminal prosecution is not merely obtaining a con- viction, but obtaining a sentence sufficient to discourage similar criminal violations by other taxpayers. Therefore, the SA should devote the same attention and energy to the sentencing process as to the investigation and processes. (

) Whenever a conviction is obtained, the SA should contact the US Probation Officer assigned to prepare the pre-sentence report, and furnish a copy of prosecution recommendation report and any other information which may speak to relevant conduct in setting forth the full magnitude of the conduct. (

) Information to be furnished to the probation officer should include, but is not limited to the following: a. An account of the harm caused to the government or other victims. b. An explanation of the applicability of any sentencing factors listed in the Federal Sentencing Guidelines Manual. c. Any indications of any relevant conduct which might be useful to the probation officer in preparing the pre-sentence report and sentencing ommendation. Note: Relevant conduct includes conduct of the defendant that is the offense of conviction, but is part of the same or similar pattern of conduct as the count(s) of conviction. The US Sentencing lines allow for consideration of uncharged conduct in calculating appropriate sentencing range. The standard of proof necessary to utilize relevant conduct for sentencing purposes is a of the evidence. (
) Upon conviction, the SAR with a prosecution recommendation may be disclosed to a US PO for the purpose of preparing the Presentence

), in certain situations, particularly for Title

offenses for failure to pay a tax, criminal restitution ordered solely as a condition of probation or supervised release severely restricts the assessment and the collection of the restitution. As a result, every effort should be made by the SA and AUSA to ensure the restitution is ordered as an independent part of the sentence and not as a condition of probation or supervised release. ommendation.

Relevant conduct includes conduct of the defendant that is outside the offense of conviction, but is part of the same or similar pattern of conduct as the count(s) of conviction. The US Sentencing Guide

lines allow for consideration of uncharged conduct in calculating the appropriate sentencing range. The standard of proof necessary to utilize relevant conduct for sentencing purposes is a preponderance of the evidence.
) Upon conviction, the SAR with a prosecution recommendation may be disclosed to a US PO for the purpose of preparing the Presentence Investiga- tion Report, contemplated by Fed. R. Crim. P.
(c). The disclosure of the SAR with a prosecution recommendation to US POs is authorized by
USC
9.6 Trial and Court Related
). However, information contained in the report shall not be if such disclosure would identify a conﬁdential informant or seriously impair civil or criminal tax investigation. (

) Occasionally, US POs will request tax information from the IRS as part of a pre-sentence investigation in a non-tax criminal matter. Disclosures may be made to probation officers in these circumstances only as provided in
(c). Treasury Regulation
provides the format that must followed in any taxpayer authorization or waiver that is submitted for the purpose of allowing a probation officer to receive tax information. (

) The SA must emphasize, to both the probation officer and the AUSA, the portance that CI attaches to the sentence imposed because of the effect it have on IRS compliance efforts among similarly situated individuals. it is vital to point out the importance of including restitution. See IRM

) Following a conviction for criminal tax violations, courts in some instances specify the sentence imposed is conditioned upon satisfactory settlement and/or payment of civil liability for taxes and penalties, and the satisfactory payment of restitution. See IRM
concerning the conditions of in civil tax matters. (

) The SAC will take whatever steps are necessary to initiate appropriate legal action in any instance where the taxpayer has failed to comply with court ordered conditions of probation or supervised release. Title
USC

) permits the disclosure of information contained in taxpayer delin- quent account ﬁles to a US PO in consideration of, preparation of, or during judicial proceeding pertaining to tax administration for the purpose of the court of any non-compliance with the terms of the taxpayer’s probation, supervised release or sentence. (
) Title

explicitly provides that, in addition to incarceration and ﬁnes, defen- dants convicted of tax offenses “shall” pay “costs of prosecution”. The costs that defendants are required to pay are limited to those set out in Title
See IRM
concerning recoverable costs of prosecution for information.
6103(h)(4). However, information contained in the report shall not be disclosed if such disclosure would identify a conﬁdential informant or seriously impair a civil or criminal tax investigation.

The SA must emphasize, to both the probation officer and the AUSA, the im- portance that CI attaches to the sentence imposed because of the effect it may have on IRS compliance efforts among similarly situated individuals. Similarly, it is vital to point out the importance of including restitution. See IRM 9.5.14.
Title

explicitly provides that, in addition to incarceration and ﬁnes, defen- dants convicted of tax offenses “shall” pay “costs of prosecution”. The costs that defendants are required to pay are limited to those set out in Title
USC
See IRM
concerning recoverable costs of prosecution for additional information.
